description: The simplicity of this app, and friction-free preview, made my last 30 minutes writing a blog post very productive. Unfortunately, I accidentally hit Ctrl + W, and discovered the hard way that Apostrophe neither auto-saves nor prompts before discarding unsaved changes. Back to my 1990s text editor…
summary: Very satisfying, until you accidentally close without saving

description: It's the essence of minimalist software. It's literally a smooth software. I installed it today and I'm loving how much pleasure Apostrophe is giving me. So fast, so practical, so logical! It's a piece of art!
Love this app! Looks great, fits well with the Gnome desktop and most importantly it gets me to write more without any distractions!
summary: Great and minimalist app for writers!

description: So many cool features, dark mode is great also side by side preview as well as word count etc are amazing features. Easy export!
summary: Best markdown editor on Linux period

description: Very clean and simple. It allows me to just sit down and focus on writing.
Apostrophe is an amazing markdown editor. It's simple, minimal, and works flawlessly
Love it, enjoying the writing experience. My wife appreciates the Dark Mode. Works great, quite a great app!
summary: Great editor, reminds me of iA Writer

description: Needs more features, themes and GUI polish. For example: no auto-save, auto-reload, highlight current line. Preferences dialog does not follow system theme. In vertical preview mode there is no visible border between code and preview so it looks odd. Your current line in Preview is not obvious / highlighted either so it takes me a while to get my bearing when synch mode is on sometimes. IMO the two pane approach is inferior to the WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get) approach in competing markdown editors like Typora and Mark Text. In those editors one can toggle between source code and WYSIWYG mode (by keyboard shortcut) as the situation requires. I really want to like this editor but it is lacking too many features, polish and requires too much screen space with it's two panes.
summary: Light on features; no user themes; missing WYSIWYG mode

description:
Totally what I need in a markdown writer. Minimal interface and controls with a preview mode. Written in beautiful native GTK+ for vanilla GNOME.

There is one thing I would like however: the ability to read markdown files with line breaks in the paragraphs. The editor appears to have a hard line wrap at 62(?) columns and there isn't an obvious way to change this. When an existing markdown file is wrapped at 80 columns with line breaks, then it becomes really hard to read without reformatting the file.
summary: Really excellent, but with some quirks

description: I've tried a lot of markdown editors over the years. Each and every one has somehow been too slow to start or too distracting to use. This one gives me a place to write, fades out the header bar and even gives me a focus mode that greys out lines/paragraphs other than the one I am working on. The syntax highlighting is just pleasant enough to be readable without distracting me with too-crazy replacements. So for my needs -- just getting thoughts out of my head somewhere -- it's perfect.
summary: The only fast and simple markdown editor for gnome

description:
This app is very simple. All it offers is a good, simple editor that is a joy to use, optional preview pane that works wonders, and a simple way to export to other formats that really helps in certain situations.

Typing up a document in this is amazing, I just start typing and the markdown formatting in harmony with the text, I don't need to reach out for shortcuts or the mouse. Before I know it, I've finished my document. Simply amazing.
Better then VSCode or code editor's. The preview and tutorial it's fantástic. Great job and work with this App it's Awesome!

It allows you to preview the markdown output in the current window instead of the source, together with it horizontally or vertically split or even in two separate windows. Scrolling in one also scrolls the other view. You can also edit the source and the result updates in real time.

This is exactly, what I needed!
summary: Just the thing, I was looking for!

description:
Great application and very responsive with a reasonably well working integration of pandoc. 

A whole catastrophe is the UX around opening or saving. For whatever reasons files are not visible in the open dialog or cannot even be found. Every single time it goes back to 'Recent files' which is annoying as you might want to open or save an adjacent file (quite a usual thing with pandoc having multiple Markdown files). Please fix!
summary: Great editor with finicky Open/Save dialogs

description: If you want a markdown text editor full of all basic features, this should be the editor you were looking for. I just get the job done.
Simple app, great design, very gnome-ish (not a bad thing). It would be nice if the user can export light theme html in dark theme edit mode.
summary: Simple and get the job done

description: I like the UI so much as well as the seamless support LaTeX
I use this app to do a lot of things from writing the README for my git repositories to writing assignments for school. Works well for both cases.
summary: Clean and simple UX with powerful features underneath it

description: While I was typing my journal, it froze and became unresponsive. I sat and waited for half an hour but after that I force closed it. It has no autosave so all my writing is gone now. Good job devs.
The problem I have is that I have to manually set advanced export options each time I export.
Only missing feature is a WYSIWYG mode like Marktext or Typora.
I don't really like how you hardcoded Adwaita and it's a bit too heavy for a simple markdown editor, but overall it's quite a decent GNOME app!
summary: A good editor with some issues

description: A Vim mode would be cool though but I'm not sure that'd be easy to implement.
Nice looking interface but lacking in functionality.

Apostrophe is a great Markdown editor. Its simplicity is coherent with the philosophy of Markdown itself, and the app is a pleasure to use. Also, the complaint of another user review has been address and now the saving dialog is displayed when closing the app.
Looks great, works great... no print button or feature.

The two other competitors for my favorite markdown editor are Mark Text and Marker. Marker fits very well into Gnome, but is lacking in features and polish. Mark Text is extremely feature rich. It has everything I could ask for, but I believe it is electron-based and it looks alien to a Gnome desktop.

I had tried Apostrophe several times before, but was never satisfied. Yesterday an update was released that added two very important features for me: Multi-window support and better window-resizing support. In addition, it's much snappier than the other two.

The reason I am not giving it five stars is that I have experienced these bugs so far:
- When switching from preview back to source, my cursor disappears.
- If preview is already active when opening a new window, I have to close and reopen the preview for it to render the text.

I would also like to see customization of fonts and font sizes in the future.

Overall, it's a great application. Easily the best for gnome.
I have tried giving this application a go a few times before, it always disappoints with how buggy it is.
Apostrophe is the best markdown editor available. There is no better solution on any other os, like windows or macos, so this could be probably one of the reasons to switch to Linux
Works well and is really useful!

Apostrophe sets out to be a minimalist editor, and succeeds at that. If you're looking for a minimal writing experience, then you'll love Apostrophe. But if you're looking for a LibreOffice-esque experience, then you'd probably dislike Apostrophe.
Very good in general. However RPM version in Fedora fails to export PDF. Flatpak version works fine (requires to install additional package, but that's ok). Overall - this is great software!
this is the best way to use markdown but can u add feature for Katex?
"Open" button need to list recent files opened by this application, not by the system wide applications.
summary: Great, but need more features to facilitate usage

description: Ich habe Apostrophe bisher nur für kurze Zeit genutzt, bin aber schon jetzt überzeugt. Die Umwandlung des Textes in PDF Format funktioniert nach der Installation des Plugins ohne Probleme und sieht sehr gut aus.
summary: Tolles Programm! Gut für Markdown -> PDF

description: i simply love this clean and distraction free interface! feels as if it had an positive effect when i try to write something complex. thank you very much for this app!
This application is well crafted. It features a very minimalistic UI with dozens of features under the hood. I write almost all my Markdown files with it.
Lo unico que le falta es soporte para mermaid charts. El resto es espectacular.
summary: El mejor editor de markdown para GNOME

description:
Me parece el mejor editor de MD, el menos intrusivo. Pero no es un gestor documental como Zettlr u Obsidian (aunque se puede integrar en este último).
Lo mejor: para escribir concentrado sin distracciones.
summary: El mejor para escribir en MD

description: En mi opinión, el mejor editor Markdown para GNOME. Me gustaría verlo con libadwaita.

Отличное приложение, понравился лаконичный интерфейс
и развитая система экспорта, включая в docx формат.
